channel.title: Brand New — Private to Pratik Ringshia

item.title: Announced: The Year in Review, Part 5: The Best in Icons, Monograms, Wordmarks, and Mascots
item.description:
“2024 Year in Review — A 10-part Series”

This installment covers logo stuff: icons, monograms, wordmarks, and mascots (which are sometimes the logo and sometimes not but it made sense to bundle them in this installment). There is no minimum or maximum number of inclusions I made… I went with as many as felt right. All selections (except for the mascots) have been rendered in Brand New red so that we can appreciate their design on a more even basis. There are no captions in these posts because I have pretty much written everything there is to write about all these things in the original posts. Perhaps also worth reminding that the order of the selections are my own and not a direct reflection of the poll results, which I do use as a barometer but ultimately I go by gut feel and what stood out the most when seen together.

Display typeface

Lofi Forest

Courtesy of
All Year-in-review Posts so far

Part 1: The Most Notable
Part 2: Recurring Trends
Part 3: The Most Not Great
Part 4: The Best Friday Likes
Part 5: The Best in Icons, Monograms, Wordmarks, and Mascots

item.title: Announced: The Year in Review, Part 4: The Best Friday Likes
item.description:
“2024 Year in Review — A 10-part Series”

No big explanation needed on this one: A selection of what I thought were the best 12 Friday Like projects out of the 85 shown in 2024.

Display typeface

Lofi Forest

Courtesy of
All Year-in-review Posts so far

Part 1: The Most Notable
Part 2: Recurring Trends
Part 3: The Most Not Great
Part 4: The Best Friday Likes
Part 5: The Best in Icons, Monograms, Wordmarks, and Mascots

 

 

Honorable
Mention

Little Bear by The Lab Saigon

 

Not the most impressive of applications but that abstracted bear face from a wine glass and stars deserves this honorable mention.See the project in Friday Likes 495

 

12

Vodka Sucks Vodka by Werner Design Werks

 

Unexpected name, deadpan typography, crooked label… it sucks in all the right ways.See the project in Friday Likes 497

 

11

Don Molinico by Auge Design

 

Never thought I would be craving stuffed peppers in a can but here we are.See the project in Friday Likes 505

 

10

Hijo de Tigre by Invade Design

 

A great spot illustration for the logo, some groovy supporting typography, and a delightful physical space. See the project in Friday Likes 506

 

9

Rosettes by Trackmeet

 

A super crisp piece of lettering and a lively color palette are too nice to resist.See the project in Friday Likes 500

 

8

La Plage.No14 by Studio Born

 

Vintage style done right.See the project in Friday Likes 499

 

7

La Plage du Martinez by Violaine & Jérémy

 

Vintage style done right-erer.See the project in Friday Likes 501

 

6

Sapiens by Marka Collective

 

I know this is an acquired taste but I loved how unconventional and untrendy this was.See the project in Friday Likes 485

 

5

Mr. Sushi by After

 

An excellent identity with a handful of elements working perfectly in sync, just like a good maki should.See the project in Friday Likes 516

 

4

Drip by Hundred Studio

 

Do you really need me to say the Drip logo has drip? Because it does.See the project in Friday Likes 517

 

3

The Penny Bun by GIRL

 

A beautiful range of elements come together effortlessly in this woodsy identity.See the project in Friday Likes 509

 

2

Bimmi by Bedow

 

The logo constructed with a typewriter is the kind of method designing that gets me going and this even had variable “weights” of the logo that were made by adding more letters. The supporting, collage-y graphics were also quite unexpected and cool.See the project in Friday Likes 494

 

1

Dirty Vegan by Jens Nilsson

 

Sadly, this restaurant is no more but it’s been immortalized in this epic case study that highlights all of the wonderful applications for this irreverent identity.See the project in Friday Likes 503

item.title: Announced: The Year in Review, Part 3: The Most Not Great
item.description:
“2024 Year in Review — A 10-part Series”

For many years labeled as “The Worst”, I changed the title to “The Most Not Great” in 2021 because some of the projects in this list had merit in some regard but perhaps missed the mark on originality or relevance or impact or that, in other words, were simply not as satisfying as some of the more engaging work we saw on Brand New the rest of 2024. (Also because “The Worst” now feels unnecessarily mean.) Selections come from the Reviewed and Noted categories and I omitted anything from the Spotted category as those don’t go through as much scrutiny. So, without further ado here are the most not great projects of 2024.

Display typeface

Lofi Forest

Courtesy of
All Year-in-review Posts so far

Part 1: The Most Notable
Part 2: Recurring Trends
Part 3: The Most Not Great
Part 4: The Best Friday Likes
Part 5: The Best in Icons, Monograms, Wordmarks, and Mascots

 

 

15

New Logo and Identity for Guggenheim by Pentagram

 
 

While the wordmark update was arguably okay, the introduction of a new, generic “G” monogram with gratuitous stylistic variations and a lackluster identity didn’t live up to the expectations of one of the most well-known cultural institutions in the world. See original post

 

14

New Logo and Packaging for Ocean Spray by Stone Strategy & Design

 
 

Winning the category of Shortest Lateral Step was this logo and packaging redesign that did absolutely nothing to improve either. See original post

 

13

New Logo and Identity for Adelaide University by Lippincott and FULLER

 
 

A very awkward and uncomfortable monogram with questionable bezier work could have been saved by a more interesting identity but that wasn’t the case here. See original post

 

12

New Logo and Identity for Ascential by DesignStudio

 
 

In a rare miss from DesignStudio about two or fifteen different design directions and ideas got crammed into a single project and unfortunately none of them were good on their own or together. See original post

 

11

New Logo and Identity for Kimberly-Clark by Someoddpilot

 
 

While the logo evolution was actually quite nice and on par with a lot of redesigns that take existing assets and dust off any unnecessary elements, this one got dragged down by an absolutely downer of an identity that, even for corporate standards, was way too corporate. See original post

 

10

New Logo and Identity for Slazenger by venturethree

 
 

A minor evolution on the panther icon, a lazy type choice, and an underdeveloped identity were not the grand slam this tennis brand needed or deserved. See original post

 

9

New Logo and Identity for Verizon by Turner Duckworth

 
 

Taking some bold swings by dropping the checkmark, embracing red, and adding a neon yellow color to the mix, Verizon left too much on the table after having built up a rather nice identity but, also, the colors are whack. See original post

 

8

New Logo and Identity for Wereldmuseum by Wieden+Kennedy Amsterdam

 
 

Attempting to be cool, hip, and weird in that very unique Dutch way — and maybe it is — this was just plain bad and awkward, delivered in a rather amateur execution. See original post

 

7

New Team Logos for Professional Women’s Hockey League by Flower Shop

 
 

This could have been such a great opportunity to shape the look of the league but giving the job to an agency that didn’t strike me as being an expert in sports led to some really lackluster logos executed as mid as possible. See original post

 

6

New Logo and Identity for Lamborghini

 
 

To be honest, I’m not 100% sure why I ranked this one so high but, I dunno, it’s Lambo… like, it should be so over the top and exciting and even annoying or douche-y but it ended up being nothing worth noting. See original post

 

5

New Logo and Identity for HMH by Lippincott

 
 

The main reason this is on here, and let it be a warning to you all, is that you do not do what they did to those “H”s in the logo and other letters in the custom typeface. Choose a terminal style, either flat or rounded but not both. Also, with the identity applications it’s like they didn’t even try to do anything remotely interesting.See original post

 

4

New Logo and Packaging for Mace Brand by Muse

 
 

From bad to bad and perhaps even worse. This should be such an empowering, kick-ass brand but this redesign further removes it from that position. See original post

 

3

New Logo and Packaging for Nutriment by Robot Food

 
 

Absolutely atrocious wordmark. There is no conceptual rationalization or strategic benefit to justify what is happening on that logo. The packaging evolution was actually kind of good but no application can be taken seriously if that logo is on it. See original post

 

2

New Logo and Livery for Aeromexico by W+K Mexico

 
 

At first I thought this was just a personal offense and that I maybe had too much nostalgia towards the old logo so it was reassuring to see so many others rally against the redesign, which is an improvement in no metric whatsoever. See original post

 

1

New Logo and Campaign for Jaguar done In-house

 
 

I realize I was relatively positive about this in my review but I’m not stubborn, oblivious, or prideful enough to ignore why so many people hated it with so much passion — there is A LOT here to warrant the top spot in this list. Only time will tell whether the heated disdain for it was warranted or not. Spoiler: This is not the last you will see of Jaguar in the Year-in-Review lists. See original post

item.title: Announced: The Year in Review Part 2: Recurring Trends
item.description:
“2024 Year in Review — A 10-part Series”

More often than not trends are considered a bad thing, which they can be the longer they drag on where it becomes more evident that others are trying to replicate the success achieved first by someone else but, at their most interesting, trends often reflect a reaction to something else within a similar timeframe where different designers arrived at similar solutions at the same time. Not all trends are bad, by the way, so this post isn’t meant to be a shaming exercise but a reflection of what the industry as a whole leaned on to create work. This list isn’t exhaustive either, I’m sure there are a number of things I didn’t spot, so I would love to see in the comments if you noticed a trend I didn’t. In terms of criteria for inclusion… nothing too strict: a trend had to happen at least three times and should have been a deviation from the norm in relation to the last two or three years. They are listed here in order of least to most recurring.

Display typeface

Lofi Forest

Courtesy of
All Year-in-review Posts so far

Part 1: The Most Notable
Part 2: Recurring Trends
Part 3: The Most Not Great
Part 4: The Best Friday Likes
Part 5: The Best in Icons, Monograms, Wordmarks, and Mascots

 

 

9 tied

These “S”s

3 projects on trend
 

Out of nowhere, these “S”s showed up on back to back days and a couple months later Colossal came out with their logo, hopefully ending the run of this very peculiar shape.

PROJECTS INCLUDED
New Logo for Colossal by Firebelly
New Logo and Identity for Apex Wheels by Gold Front
New Logo and Identity for Assape by Abmo
 

9 tied

These “M”s

3 projects on trend
 

Looking a little limp, this treatment of the “M” is not the most flattering, yet three projects thought it was.

PROJECTS INCLUDED
New Logo and Identity for MassArt by Moth Design
New Name and Logo for OH!SOME
New Logo and Identity for Museum of West African Art by Human After All
 

8 tied

These Eyes

4 projects on trend
 

Vintage cartoon eyes were all the rage with some of this year’s mascots.

PROJECTS INCLUDED
New Logo and Identity for Nik Bentel Studio by Little Troop
New Logo and Identity for Bachan’s by Stout
New Logo and Identity for Lamar Advertising by Heyo
New Identity for Sizzler by Tavern
 

8 tied

Monochromatic

4 projects on trend
 

A good monochromatic palette goes a long way and these four identities put their subtly shifting hues to good use.

PROJECTS INCLUDED
New Logo and Identity for New Aim by Christopher Doyle & Co.
New Logo, Identity, and Packaging for Impossible Foods by Jones Knowles Ritchie and In-house
New Logo, Identity, and Packaging for Manischewitz by Jones Knowles Ritchie
New logo and identity for Gobi Cashmere by Mucho
 

7

Spurless Geometrics

8 projects on trend
 

Geometric sans serifs were all the rage in the mid- to late 2010s and have been a consistent go-to type choice for decades but this year we got a heavy dose of the sub-genre of spurless geometric sans serifs. Since Jaguar adopted this approach, I think it will mark the end of its run for a while because who wants to copy the brand that copies nothing?

PROJECTS INCLUDED
New Logo and Identity for Pienso by Pentagram
New logo and identity for Daylight Computer Company by The Office of Ordinary Things
New Logo and Identity for L’Observatoire de Paris-PSL by Graphéine
New Logo and Identity for Prolaio by The Collected Works
New Logo for Mophie
New Logo for Verbatim
New Logo and Packaging for Nutriment by Robot Food
New Logo and Campaign for Jaguar done In-house
 

6

Giant Footer Logos

9 projects on trend
 

Patient zero for this trend was 2023’s redesign of the Wolff Olins website that introduced a giant version of its logo to the footer and the treatment took like wildfire this year. I’m sure there are dozens more that I missed from all the projects shown on Brand New but these ones were particularly juicy footers.

PROJECTS INCLUDED
New Logo for Spellbook by Focus Lab and In-house
New Logo and Identity for Fluz by Koto
New Logo and Identity for Guild by COLLINS
New Logo and Identity for Eppo by Moving Brands
New Logo and Identity for Spectrum.Life by UnitedUs
New Logo and Identity for Kindsight by Gold Front
New Logo and Identity for Mayda by Studio Kiln
New Logo and Identity for The Man Cave by TRiC Studio
New Identity for New Museum by Athletics
 

5

Conference Stage Mock-up

11 projects on trend
 

I realize that recurring mock-ups are nothing new on Brand New but this one in particular, in 2024 in particular, came up more often than ever before and, personally, I do not understand its appeal. The empty auditorium, the uncomfortable chairs, the ridiculously wide screen ratio, and the fact that this is one of the least likely scenarios one would experience a brand is so confusing. Coincidentally (or not), it was one of the top-selling mock-ups on The Brand Identity’s store this year.

PROJECTS INCLUDED
New Logo and Identity for Global Commons Alliance by Johnson Banks
New Logo and Identity for LiveKit by The Collected Works
New Logo and Identity for RIX Riga Airport by Asketic
New Logo and Identity for Stereolabs by Pentagram
New Logo and Identity for FM by Prophet
New Logo and Identity for Syenex by Essen
New Name, Logo, and Identity for Zaffra by Dragon Rouge
New Logo and Identity for EcoSecurities by Thisaway
New Name, Logo, and Identity for Frank Penny by Bedow
New Logo and Identity for Spectrum.Life by UnitedUs
New Logo and Identity for Centersquare by Jones Knowles Ritchie
 

4 tied

Next-level Ligatures

12 projects on trend
 

Ligatures have been around forever and have long been an easy way of customizing typography to make a wordmark stand out but this year, more wordmarks took more daring approaches to ligatures in unexpected pairs beyond “fi” and “fl”. Some to more success than others.

PROJECTS INCLUDED
New Logo and Identity for Brand New
New Logo and Identity for Iittala by Aleksi Tammi and In-house
New Logo and Packaging for Nutriment by Robot Food
New Logo and Identity for Guild by COLLINS
New Logo and Identity for Brooklyn Museum by Other Means
New Logo for HMD
New Logo and Identity for commercetools by Styles+Partners
New Logo and Identity for Thistle by Pearlfisher
New Name, Logo, and Identity for The Mora by DesignStudio
New Logo and Identity for Decathlon by Wolff Olins
New Logo and Identity for NorthAlley by Studio Fable
New Logo and Identity for McInroy & Wood by Sparks Studio
 

4 tied

Seeing Red

12 projects on trend
 

A big embrace of big use of red was a bit of a surprise this year as it is often used more as an accent than a full coating. Big fan of the trend and would love to see more of it.

PROJECTS INCLUDED
New Logo, Identity, and Website for Murray’s Cheese by Base Design
New Name, Logo, and Identity for Joves de Barcelona by Pràctica (now Principi & SMLXL)
New Logo and Identity for Tattoox by Morbo, THRU, and Vagrant
New Logo and Identity for MSI 24 by Studio Dumbar/DEPT.
New Logo and Identity for Verizon by Turner Duckworth
New Logo and Identity for Indify by CENTER
New Logo and Packaging for Coffee Foundation by Andrea Flemma and Paolo Vendramini
New Logo and Packaging for Hyro by Electric Brands
New Logo, Identity, and Packaging for Impossible Foods by Jones Knowles Ritchie and In-house
New Logo and Identity for Abu Dhabi Festival by no one
New Logo and Identity for Brompton House by UnitedUs
New Logo and Identity for Interior Design Show by Sali Tabacchi
 

3 tied

Condensed Grotesques

15 projects on trend
 

Grotesques, which tend to have a subtle human touch that other sans serifs lack have always had a place in the design industry’s arsenal but, this year, we all let it rip with this style with a big emphasis on condensed structures. From proprietary to retail typefaces, there was no shortage of this crowd-pleaser.

PROJECTS INCLUDED
New Logo and Identity for OpenResearch by Play
New Logo and Identity for Nederlander Theatres by Fiasco Design
New Logo and Identity for Pomus by Sömestr
New Logo and Identity for RSPCA by Jones Knowles Ritchie
New Logo and Identity for Sendwave by DesignStudio
New Logo and Identity for Foxes Club by Thisaway
New Logo and Identity for U Group by For The People
New Logo, Identity, and Packaging for Impossible Foods by Jones Knowles Ritchie and In-house
New Logo and Identity for INZMO by Tabasco Agency
New Logo and Identity for Klarna done In-house
New Logo and Identity for WRAP by Among Equals
New Logo and Identity for Adelaide University by Lippincott and FULLER
New Logo and Identity for Bancomat by Landor
New Name, Logo, and Packaging for Slather by SICKDOGWOLFMAN
New Logo and Identity for Théâtre Sénart by Graphéine
 

3 tied

Gooey Corners

15 projects on trend
 

As an antidote or a response to sharp ink traps — a trend most of us are ready to see go away — we had ink “swells” and gooey, outwardly-curvy corners permeate typography as letters oozed unto the screen and into each other for a cuddly, human effect.

PROJECTS INCLUDED
New Logo and Identity for Crumbl by Turner Duckworth
New Logo and Identity for Novonesis by Anomaly
New Logo and Identity for XR by Athletics
New Logo and Identity for Nik Bentel Studio by Little Troop
New Logo and Identity for U Group by For The People
New Logo and Identity for Qasa by Bold Scandinavia
New Logo and Identity for CoppaFeel! by Livity
New Logo and Identity for Trait by Studio zur Strassen
New Logo, Identity, and Packaging for Drumroll by Gander
New Logo and Identity for KATSEYE by HuskyFox
New Logo and Packaging for Ayoh by CENTER
New Logo and Identity for Being Health by The Working Assembly
New Logo, Identity, and Website for Murray’s Cheese by Base Design
New Logo, Identity, and Packaging for The Dinner Ladies by Universal Favourite
New Logo and Identity for Contentsquare by Saffron
 

3 tied

Angled Logos

15 projects on trend
 

Once more, nothing new here… logos have been set an angle many times before but not as many in the same span of 12 months. I checked against last year and there were only about 8. Well known to convey optimism and a forward-moving mindset, angled logos maybe serve as the subconscious therapy we didn’t know we needed to feel better about the state of the world.

PROJECTS INCLUDED
New Logo and Identity for Gustini by Koto
New Logo and Packaging for Ayoh by CENTER
New Logo and Identity for DaGrasso Pizza by Redkroft
New Logo and Identity for Freshways by White Bear
New Logo for Galavisión
New Logo for IDW Publishing
New Logo for JoyJolt by Pearlfisher
New Logo and Identity for JUBEL by Earthling Studio
New Logo for Lunchly
New Logo and Packaging for Munchies by Vocabulary
New Logo for OXY by Arrivals + Departures
New Logo and Identity for Saray by Monroe
New Logo and Identity for Shorter & Sharp by Brandspace
New Spirit Brand and Athletics Identity for Delta College by atomicvibe design lab
New Logo and Identity for Karnival by Thisaway
 

2

Living on the Edge

23 projects on trend
 

Credit for noticing this trend goes to Nolen Strals and once it was pointed out I started noticing in posts published immediately after. Upon further inspection of all of 2024’s files it was clear as day: Designers like to live on the edge. Or, at least, they like to place laptops, phones, brochures, business cards, and packaging poking out of a myriad of ledges. The source of this trend are mock-up templates that, probably in an effort to make the empty vessels look more interesting and engaging, started placing objects on the verge of falling down to attract designers’ attention.

PROJECTS INCLUDED
New Logo and Identity for A&W (Canada) by Rethink
New Name, Logo and Identity for Airtime by ODA
New Logo and Identity for Bongénie by Base Design
New Logo and Identity for Betano by Nomad
New Logo, Identity, and Packaging for Cordon Bleu by LG2
New Logo, Identity, and Packaging for Cuddle by Earthling Studio
New Logo and Identity for Darco by Hunt
New Logo and Identity for FM by Prophet
New Logo and Identity for Snapchat Ghost by Play
New Logo and Identity for IPAI by LIT
New Logo and Identity for Klarna done In-house
New Logo and Identity for McGrath by Toben
New Logo and Identity for Fonds de Dotation Marie-Thérèse Allier by Brand Brothers
New Logo and Identity for OpenResearch by Play
New Logo and Identity for ŌUSHQ by TinyWins
New Logo and Identity for Pienso by Pentagram
New Logo and Identity for ShareFile by Athletics
New Name, Logo, and Identity for Viction by Rice Studios
New Logo, Identity, and Packaging for The Coconut Cult by &Walsh
New Logo and Identity for Centersquare by Jones Knowles Ritchie
New Logo, Identity, and Packaging for Aliva by KIND
New Logo and Identity for Vast by Manual
New Logo and Identity for Théâtre Sénart by Graphéine
 

1

That Blue

35 projects on trend
 

That Blue has long been a recurring inside joke on Brand New and while we’ve seen dozens if not hundreds of projects use That Blue over the years — including in 2020 when I selected it as one of the top trends of the year — this year it just popped off. What’s weird is that, in these 12 months, it never felt overwhelming or come across as an exhausting trend, it just flew under the radar but as I looked back at all the work, I was flabbergast that more than 30 projects used That Blue (in one of its many variations) as the primary color.

PROJECTS INCLUDED
New Logo and Identity for Bongénie by Base Design
New Logo, Identity, and Packaging for Cuddle by Earthling Studio
New Logo and Identity for F.C. København by Kontrapunkt
New Logo and Identity for Full Pin by Rethink
New Logo and Identity for Hubbl done In-house
New Logo and Identity for Kimberly-Clark by Someoddpilot
New Logo and Identity for Kleenex by Turner Duckworth
New Logo and Packaging for Munchies by Vocabulary
New Logo and Identity for Myota by Kuba&Friends
New Name, Logo, and Identity for Nexus by SomeOne
New Logo and Identity for OLALA! by Everland
New Logo and Identity for Peter Schmidt Group done In-house
New Logo and Identity for Plutus by Together
New Logo and Identity for RSPCA by Jones Knowles Ritchie
New Logo and Identity for State Street by Lippincott
New Logo and Identity for Breakthrough T1D by Siegel+Gale
New Logo for Europa Clipper by House of van Schneider
New Logo for Melbourne United by SouthSouthWest
New Logo for Finder
New Logo and Identity for Sola by Monigle
New Logo for American Home Shield
New Logo and Identity for Nearmap by DesignStudio
New Logo, Identity, and Packaging for Opill by Elmwood
New Logo for NTWRK by Hype Type Studio
New Logo and Identity for Resugar by SIDE ST
New Logo for CNI
New Logo and Identity for The Breman by Matchstic
New Logo and Identity for Diffblue by Together
New Logo for Global Blue by ArtFeelsGood
New Logo and Identity for SCB done In-house
New Logo for Ligue Nationale de Basket (LNB) by Dragon Rouge
New Logo and Identity for Doppelmayr by KMS Team
New Logo and Identity for Toilet Twinning by Wildish & Co.
New Logo and Identity for KGNU by Order
New Logo for La Ligue contre le cancer by W Conran Design

item.title: Announced: The Year in Review Part 1: The Most Notable
item.description:
“2024 Year in Review — A 10-part Series”

This year’s Most Notable project will not come as a surprise given how much chatter it generated and how, seemingly, if you didn’t want your account revoked, you HAD to have (and share) an opinion about Jaguar on LinkedIn. Normally I might have preceded that opening sentence with a “Spoiler” warning but that would be like telling you Bruce Willis is dead the whole time in The Sixth Sense. The run-up to the number 1 spot is a little more interesting as there were some relatively big moves from a couple of unexpected brands this year — some for the better, some for the worse, and some for the futility of not achieving much change.

This first part of the Year in Review includes the “Most Notable” projects of the year, which are neither the best nor the worst, simply the most high-profile. Below, in order of notoriety not just on Brand New but on all kinds of media are 2024’s Most Notable brand and identity work. In the small blurbs for each project, very little new opinion is offered as plenty has already been written in the original posts (and in the comments), so the blurbs are more for context.

A couple of additional notes

There will be no regular posts for these next two weeks given that (one) it’s the Holidays and (two) it’s the slowest time of the year in terms of traffic on Brand New so it’s not fair for any new work to go largely ignored.

Regular posting will resume January 6.

If you are reading this in an RSS reader, you are going to want to see it on the site as there is some heavy formatting involved.

The home page has been slightly modified to show the lists as they get posted. It will go back to normal in January.

Display typeface

Lofi Forest

Courtesy of
All Year-in-review Posts so far

Part 1: The Most Notable
Part 2: Recurring Trends
Part 3: The Most Not Great
Part 4: The Best Friday Likes
Part 5: The Best in Icons, Monograms, Wordmarks, and Mascots

 

 

24

New Logo and Identity for Brooklyn Museum by Other Means

 
 

Not the biggest or most well-known of museums in New York but a significant departure and relatively daring redesign for a borough favorite.See original post

 

23

New Logo and Identity for Imperia by Landor

 
 

A category leader in the delectable niche of pasta-making, Imperia retained the legacy of its logo but kneaded some fun new elements into its brand. See original post

 

22

New Logo and Identity for Iittala by Aleksi Tammi and In-house

 
 

One of the most well-known and best-regarded glassmakers in the world as well as an icon of Finnish industry, Iittala raised plenty of eyebrows as it abandoned its logo and “i” mark of excellence in favor of a more fashion-oriented design. See original post

 

21

New Logo, Identity, and Livery for Air India by Futurebrand

 

As far as positive rebrandings go, Air India’s was one of the most beneficial with a drastic makeover from a dated logo and identity to one better poised to be the country’s flag carrier. See original post

 

20

New Logo and Livery for Aeromexico by W+K Mexico

 
 

On the opposite end of the spectrum, Mexico’s flag carrier, Aeromexico, received a saddening downgrade. See original post

 

19

New Logo and Identity for Banco Itaú by Pentagram and In-house

 
 

Keeping some equity with the logo placed at the bottom of a holding shape, Banco Itaú joined the 2020s with a livelier, more colorful, and dynamic new logo and identity. See original post

 

18

New Logo, Identity, and Packaging for Impossible Foods by Jones Knowles Ritchie and In-house

 
 

As the trailblazer in the I-can’t-believe-it’s-not-meat, plant-based, meat substitute category, Impossible could have stuck with its recognizable bright mint color palette but risk becoming obsolete as the competition grew so, going against expectations, it embraced meat-red as its primary brand color.See original post

 

17

New Logo and Identity for Speedo by Anomaly

 
 

A brand that is probably not top-of-mind for most people but still the most well-known name in the competitive (and now recreational) swimwear category, Speedo did some laps with a subtle evolution to its recognizable logo. See original post

 

16

New Logo and Identity for Sandisk by ELA Advertising and In-house

 
 

Squeezing in at the last minute before regular publication ended on Brand New, Sandisk saw an opportunity to ride the wave of interest in wacky rebrandings (courtesy of Jaguar) as this somewhat ubiquitous (and, hence, taken-for-granted) memory card brand took a bold swing with a crazy logo.See original post

 

15

New Logo and Packaging for Kit Kat by Sterling Brands

 
 

A popular candy bar that has never been a beacon of great design got a great update that now almost literally embodies the product — saw these at the checkout lane recently and they look great. See original post

 

14

New Logo and Identity for RSPCA by Jones Knowles Ritchie

 
 

A painfully outdated identity for a great organization got the grooming sesh it very much deserved for a vibrant new presence. See original post

 

13

New Logo and Identity for Docusign done In-house

 
 

You’ve probably signed more Docusigns than you care to remember and part of it is the ubiquity of this online platform. Fun fact: This was the second most-visited project of the year, which was kind of surprising — to find out which one was the number 1, you will have to scan through the newsletter arriving in your inbox on December 30. See original post

 

12

New Logo, Identity, and Packaging for Manischewitz by Jones Knowles Ritchie

 
 

Although it didn’t have much competition at the national level, Manischewitz was still very much in need of something to make it stand out and become more memorable — some good ol’ chutzpah got the job done. See original post

 

11

New Logo and Identity for Decathlon by Wolff Olins

 

As one of the biggest European retailers, Decathlon has a humongous footprint to make an impression so, surely, in time, the new icon will become synonymous with it. See original post

 

10

New Logo and Identity for MotoGP by Pentagram

 
 

For fans of things that go really fast, few brands carry as much excitement as MotoGP, which adopted some of the traits of its new sister company, Formula 1, also owned by Liberty Media Corporation. See original post

 

9

New Logo and Identity for Mozilla by Jones Knowles Ritchie

 
 

Google’s Chrome and Apple’s Safari may have the most recognition in the browser space but perhaps neither would exist without the groundbreaking Mozilla that re-adopted its dinosaur logo before going extinct. See original post

 

8

New Logo and Identity for American Girl by Pentagram

 
 

Not my cup of tea but hundreds of thousands of hours have probably been spent by little girls (and boys) on fake tea-drinking sessions with these dolls, which remain a toy classic. See original post

 

7

New Identity for The LEGO Group by Interbrand and In-house

 
 

It’s hard to believe LEGO hadn’t had a proper, fully thought out identity before this but it was well worth the wait as everything here clicked into place. See original post

 

6

New Logo and Identity for Kleenex by Turner Duckworth

 
 

Like LEGO above, Kleenex was a victim of its own success with no identity to help brand it as the company behind the genericized brand name that is better known for its wackadoodle box designs. See original post

 

5

New Logo and Packaging for Mountain Dew done In-house

 
 

The battle of the soda brands never ends and Mountain Dew, popular with extreme sports, is now trying to carve some room with the outdoorsy types. See original post

 

4

New Logo and Identity for Guggenheim by Pentagram

 
 

Unlike its Brooklyn neighbor shown at the top of this list, this is one of THE most well-known museums not just in New York but around the world and with such an iconic identity any little change could send the design industry into a frenzy. It did. See original post

 

3

New Logo and Identity for Verizon by Turner Duckworth

 
 

One of the major telcos in the U.S., the Verizon name has so much equity and power that they decided to abandon the checkmark for the first time in more than 20 years. It’s a big deal. See original post

 

2

New Logo and Identity for PayPal by Pentagram

 
 

Before the Jaguar story swooped in at the end of the year to steal everyone’s thunder, PayPal had been the biggest design story of the year and not necessarily for the right reasons… mostly, its lack of design. See original post

 

1

New Logo and Campaign for Jaguar done In-house

 
 

No notes. This is how you get noticed. For better or worse. Stay tuned for more surprise appearances by Jaguar in our other Year-in-Review lists. See original post

item.title: Linked: Yes We Canned
item.description:
Visit Link

Tired of email spam this Holiday season? Boston- and Philly-based A&G took spam to a whole new level as an OpenType-SVG font that has been “carved and meticulously handcrafted” from actual SPAM®. A $12 donation not only gets you the working font but you help raise money to battle food insecurities in A&G’s communities, with the proceeds going to The Greater Boston Food Bank and Philabundance.

item.title: Noted: New Logo and Identity for Contentsquare by Saffron
item.description:
“Journey to the Center of the Square”

(Est. 2012) “Contentsquare is the all-in-one experience intelligence platform designed to be easily used by anyone that cares about digital journeys. With our flexible and scalable platform, you quickly get a deep understanding of your customers’ whole online journey. Our AI-powered insights provide those ‘ah ha’ moments you need to deliver the right digital experiences. You get to work faster and smarter, with the confidence to know what to do next to improve. ﻿Leading brands use Contentsquare to grow their business, deliver more customer delight, and move with greater efficiency in a constantly changing world. Our insights optimize the experience on over 1.3 million websites worldwide.”

Design by
Saffron

Related links
Saffron project page
Contentsquare blog post

Relevant quote
With an ambitious directive from leadership, Contentsquare set out to become the ‘go-to platform for understanding people.’ To align with this vision, we helped position Contentsquare as the brand that offers actionable insights into people’s behaviour through effortless analytics. This positioning not only reflects the company’s new direction, but also resonates with what drives and inspires Contentsquare's people.

Central to the identity is the graphic language, designed to convey three key principles that the platform promises: Space for Clarity, Customer Journeys, and Human Understanding. Moving away from the blue hues that saturate the tech industry, the design leans into a warm and sophisticated colour palette that sets Contentsquare apart within their category.

The identity expresses the feeling of ease and understanding inherent in using the platform. By keeping it simple, the humanity at the heart of the brand can shine through.

Contentsquare’s typographic system combines two font families to bring their voice to life with clarity and consistency. New Edge Rounded, a modern grotesque with rounded interiors and angular corners, captures a sense of ease and understanding, while Inter adds versatility, working seamlessly across everything from body copy to user interfaces.

Images (opinion after)

Opinion
The old logo was fine but generic. The monogram-slash-icon did a decent job of putting a “square” inside the “C” to pay off on the name. The lock-up relationship was kind of wild though with the giant monogram looking like it's going to Pac-Man the wordmark. The new logo also takes a cue from the name and wedges a square into the counter and negative spaces of the letterforms, some to more success than others. The “C”, “O”, “S”, and “Q” look great with that treatment but the “E” and the “R” are very awkward. It's a shame the name doesn't have the same amount of letters in both words so that the monospace-ish wordmark could be full-justified instead of leaving the poor “T” out on its own. Still, a good logo that yields a really nice shorthand version where the “CSQ” trio look awesome blended together and with the rhythm of the matching counterspaces. The identity gets a little wonky as it adopts New Edge 666 Rounded as its primary typeface and while it looks arguably okay at large sizes and in small doses, experiencing it in smaller sizes and higher doses on their website is low-key appalling. It's not just painful to look at but it's actually difficult to read. The gooey, connecting, rounded-corner approach is extended to the supporting graphics and holding shapes that make things feel more complicated than they need to be. I mean, in principle it's fine and it's properly executed but something about those holding shapes with the type indenting them feels forced and awkward and there are too many lines going in too many directions. Overall, this has a strong foundation in the full and shorthand logos but the identity gets too complicated and makes an already unclear platform more confusing to understand at a quick glance.

item.title: Reviewed: Friday Likes 519: From Tuux and Bienal, Chris Chapman, and HUGMUN
item.description:
“From Tuux and Bienal, Chris Chapman, and HUGMUN”

Some fun packaging this week, featuring two ambitious custom bottles, with work from Mexico City and Mérida, London, and Copenhagen.

Acrónimo by Tuux and Bienal

Acrónimo is a spirit producer in the state of Chihuahua in Mexico, where a specific kind of plant (of the genus Dasylirion) grows in its dessert and is the main ingredient in sotol, one of the two spirits distilled by Acrónimo and the other being gin. If I understand things correctly, the bottle has been designed by Mexico City-based Tuux while the logo and other design elements have been created by Mérida-based Bienal. The bottle is pretty amazing, with a rough texture echoing the desert and a large, recessed, smoothed out circle that is to signify a window into the soul… sure, it’s a little woo-woo but it looks so nice. The bottle also has an indentation that goes all around the squared structure where the label neatly wraps around. Looking like an alien inscription, the logo is groovy and unexpected but also a bold contrast to the minimalist design. A brief behind-the-scenes about the bottle can be found here — so well thought-out. See full project

Agua de Madre by Chris Chapman

Agua de Madre is a water kefir brand brewed in London, UK. In case you are wondering as I was, here is a description of it in layman’s terms from Reddit: “water kefir is a better and more potent probiotic than kombucha. Kombucha is too yeasty. Water kefir can be brewed to contain trillions of CFU of bacteria with minimal yeast.” The packaging, designed by UK-based Chris Chapman, avoids the usual earthy and overly healthy aesthetics of most fermented drinks and instead opts for a more soda-esque and fun vibe with a heavily layered concoction of vintage, slightly cheesy typefaces coming together as if they were stickers haphazardly placed on top of each other. Good for the gut, excellent for the eyes. See full project

Resibo by HUGMUN

Resibo is a skincare and cosmetics brand based in Świdnica, Poland, that recently launched a new range of shower gels and hand soaps. The packaging, designed by Copenhagen, Denmark-based HUGMUN, starts with another great custom bottle that looks like the facade to an opulent Art Deco building. Looking almost like marble or limestone, with its off-white hue, the tone-on-tone effect that results from the tiered grooves is beautiful. The serif typography — which I am sitting here embarrassingly not remembering its name but that I know deep in my heart that I do know it — is a very unexpected choice that makes the bottle look like a vintage book cover, in the best of ways. The color choices are also spot on, especially the red but I would probably choose the brown one because that combo of sandalwood and fig with smokey notes actually sounds to die for. See full project

About Spotted posts
No further images are included. No opinion is given. Not even a punny title. These are just… spotted. Best available link to learn more about the change (or the company) provided in the link above. If you don’t see “VISIT LINK” above there is no link available. Poll and comments are open.
